You Feel Something Real About Something Fake

We don't understand it either, but it keeps happening and we've stopped questioning it.

Our 37% accuracy rate is based on a study we conducted in Barnaby's kitchen. Sample size: 12 photos. Control group: none. Peer review: Clementine said "sure, sounds right." IRB status: we don't know what that is.

Every photograph is a person who expected to be remembered. We are all that person.

The Steamer Trunk

Barnaby Crisp found the trunk in a storage unit in Trenton, New Jersey, in the spring of 2023. It belonged to his great-aunt Ethel, a woman he'd met exactly twice and remembered primarily for her opinion that margarine was a government conspiracy. Inside: forty-seven photographs of people nobody in the Crisp family could name.

He held a picture of a woman laughing on a porch — genuinely laughing, head thrown back, one hand on a railing — and realized that someone once loved her desperately and now she was nothing but silver halide and mystery. He called Clementine Funk, his business partner and the only person he knew who owned a flatbed scanner. (Clementine's legal dispute with Ancestry.com remains ongoing and she has been advised not to discuss it, which she does constantly.)

They built Microfiche Memoirs in Barnaby's apartment over six weeks. The AI was trained on obituaries, romance novels, and a Wikipedia article about grain elevators that got in there by accident. The TED Talk incident occurred four months later. Barnaby will not elaborate on what happened at TED. The footage has been removed. The cease-and-desist was mutual.

We charge you nothing to feel something. Ancestry charges $30/month to feel the same thing but with a family tree graphic.

The scanner hums. The dust settles. Somewhere, a photograph waits in a drawer for someone who will never open it.

The Equipment & The Emergency

One cannot exist without the other

Meet Mildred

Mildred is our Epson Perfection V39 flatbed scanner. She was manufactured on March 14, 2021, in Suwa, Nagano, Japan. She arrived in a box that said "precision imaging" and we have held her to that promise every day since.

  • Scans at 4800 DPI (she prefers 600, like the rest of us, she has limits)
  • Pulls slightly to the left, like all of us
  • Makes a sound at startup that Clementine describes as "hopeful"
  • Has processed 4,211 photographs of strangers
  • Once scanned Barnaby's hand by accident. The AI said he was a fisherman from Gloucester. He was not.

Mildred's retirement plan consists of being placed on a shelf with a small plaque that reads "She Saw Everything."
